reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Hiking theme page turner
reviews.reviewText: I loved the atmosphere of this one- the Appalachian trail, the inn, the mountain town full of secrets -but I didn’t really love our “sleuth,” Abby. She basically just stumbled across clues and information and didn’t really piece anything together without putting herself in danger. Definitely a page-turner, though, and now I’m up for a good hike.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Wow - not what I expected
reviews.reviewText: A very easy read that keeps you attached as though you are a part of the story. The story seems simple and easy to project - until it isn't and you're wondering where that twist came from. I really enjoyed the simple way MS Miranda told a complicated story, she didn't loose you or bore you and succeeded in keeping me guessing. Now I just have to decide which of her work I'll read next lol!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars if you love a twistery…
reviews.reviewText: This is pretty good one. The mysterious disappearances of hikers from a small town in the mountains of North Carolina rolls along at a decent pace. There’s not a lot to dig into with the characters, but all in all, it’s enjoyable enough to continue reading in order to find out what’s going on. The twist is a bit frustrating when revealed fairly late on in the story due to a narrator hold back. Either way, a decent read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Good plot line and mystery
reviews.reviewText: This book started good, then slowed, but picked up again. I did not see the ending coming and was very surprised to see how the whole mystery wrapped up. Good book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I am 34 years old. I have tried again and again over the years to become a reader with no success until I tried this book! I was able to read this without my mind wondering and actually get into the story and feel all the emotions and suspense! It was a great read! And the first book I have ever finished in my life! Suspenseful to the very end and I would never have guessed the ending!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I have read most of Megan Miranda's books. Megan is very good at describing the places and people who feature in her novels, so much so you feel like you are right there. Dividing up The Last to Vanish into 5 parts was a fantastic way to give context to time periods and when major events happen in the town of Cutter’s Pass and The Passage Inn.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 16, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Another Winning Book by Megan Miranda
reviews.reviewText: Megan Miranda is a brilliant person and a beautiful writer. All of her novels shine with incredible imagery and complex plots. I believe her writing is not to be read quickly, by skimming the content to get to the drama. Miranda writes with an intensity that makes the reader slow down and visualize the environment and the emotion of the world she writes about. Her work does not drag, however, as the pace of the book steadily develops and draws the reader into the story. Her characters are well developed and complex, with each character becoming more involved with the others as the plot unfolds. Miranda's knowledge of the people and the atmosphere of western North Carolina makes for a remarkable background for her novels. The Last To Vanish is a perfect example of Miranda's skillful writing, plot development, and character creation. I have read each of her novels for adults, and I thoroughly enjoyed the experience of reading this latest publication. All of her novels are excellent, as each paragraph is well thought out and intense. Spend time with her books, and enjoy the work she puts forth.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2022
reviews.reviewText: I recently read The Last to Vanish by Megan Miranda. This is the story of a woman, Abby, who works at an inn in western North Carolina. The big draw of this picturesque vacation spot is the hiking, rafting, general outdoorsiness. In the past, there have been problems when people have gone missing on the hiking trails. When a mysterious guest checks in, Abby's curiosity is peaked. She discovers that the guest, Trey, is the brother of one of those who had disappeared. As Trey begins his exploration of his brother's actions Abby is surprised by what she discovers while trying to assist him. All is not right at the inn and the evidence is mounting that something is very wrong.While I don't really consider Megan Miranda's books heart pounding thrillers, this is more thriller than usual. The mystery is interesting and complicated. The story is intriguing and grabs you quickly. The writing is pleasant, as always. I wished it was a bit shorter, but at 336 pages the length doesn't seem outrageous. Overall, this was very enjoyable and my favorite by this author so far. Can't wait until the next.
Lots of twists and turns, explanations and details on point. Good read

reviews.reviewTitle: My last time with this author.
reviews.reviewText: As with her other books, I do not find all the plot lines concluded. Very disconcerting for a mystery. Why did Georgia have a key to a locker with items from previous murders? Why the letter “J” on the key? While the end is interesting (agreeing to keep secrets) the conclusion was at a very different pace than the rest of the book with little time for development of motives or insight into character. I find the writing style difficult to read at times, having to go back for clear plot. Alas, my last time with this author.
